tuv.seg: When I'm Gone
我若离去
Death is always a surprise.
死亡总在意料之外。
No one expects it.
没有人能够预感到它。
Not even terminal patients think they are going to die in a day or two. In a week, maybe.
即使濒临死亡的病人认为他们将在一两天之内死去，或许，在一周内。
But only when this particular week is the next week.
但这个特殊的一周将会是下一个一周。
We are never ready. It is never the right time.
我们从没有做好准备在对的时间去面对死亡。
By the time it comes, you will not have done all the things that we wanted to.
直到它到来，我们或许也未做完我们想要做的所有的事情，这个结局总是出乎意料的到来。
The end always comes as a surprise, and it's a tearful moment for widows and a bore for the children who don't really understand what a funeral is (thank God).
对于寡妇来说，它是个催泪的悲伤时刻；对于还不理解葬礼孩子来说，它是一个使人讨厌的事情。
It was no different with my father.
对我父亲而言也是这样。
In fact, his death was even more unexpected.
实则，他的死亡更加的出乎意料。
He was gone at age 27.
他27岁时就离开了。
The same age that claimed the lives of several famous musicians.
同样的年龄，死亡索取了那些著名的音乐家的生命。
He was young. Way too young.
他英年早逝，太过年轻。
My father was not a musician and neither a famous person.
我的父亲既不是音乐家也不是一个有名的人。
Cancer doesn't pick its victims.
癌症不会挑选他作为牺牲者。
He was gone when I was young, and I learned what a funeral was because of him.
他在我很小的时候就去世了，因为他，我知道了什么是葬礼。
I was 8 and half, old enough to miss him for a lifetime.
当时，我八岁半，太过早的一生思念他。
Had he died before, I wouldn't have memories. I would feel no pain.
如果我没有他去世之前的记忆，我将不会感到痛苦。
But I wouldn't have a father in my life. And I had a father.
我有一个父亲，但是他去世之后我的生活中将没有父亲。
I had a father who was both firm and fun.
我有一个坚强有趣的父亲。
Someone who would tell a joke before grounding me. That way, I wouldn't feel so bad. Someone who kissed me on the forehead before I went to sleep.
他在我还没学会走路之前就给我讲笑话，那个方式，使我不会感到太糟糕；他趁我睡着后偷偷的亲吻我的额头。
A habit which I passed on to my children. Someone who forced me to support the same football team he supported, and who explained things better than my mother.
他会强迫我和他支持相同的足球队，这个习惯我把它传给了我的孩子，他解释事情比我妈妈清楚。
Do you know what I mean?
你明白我所说的吗？
A father like that is someone to be missed.
我的父亲就像我所思念的这样。
He never told me he was going to die. Even when he was lying on a hospital bed with tubes all over him, he didn't say a word.
他从没告诉我他会离开我，即使他在医院的病床上插着管子躺着的时候，他一个字也没说。
My father made plans for the next year even though he knew he wouldn't be around in the next month.
我的父亲安排好了明年的计划即使他知道他不能活到下个月。
Next year, we would go fishing, we would travel, we would visit places we've never been.
明年，我们将去尝试一些我们以前从未做过的钓鱼，旅行，和参观一些地方。
Next year would be an amazing year. We lived the same dream.
明年将是一个令人惊异的一年，我们做着相同的梦。
I believe - actually I'm sure - he thought this should bring luck.
事实上，我坚信，他认为这样做可以带来好运。
He was a superstitious man.
他是个迷信的人。
Thinking about the future was the way he found to keep hope alive.
带着活着的希望认为未来总有出路。
The bastard made me laugh until the very end.
这种假的希冀让我发笑直到最后。
He knew about it. He didn't tell me. He didn't see me crying.
他知道我不相信，他从没有告诉我，他从未看见我在哭。
And suddenly, the next year was over before it even started.
忽然间，明年在他还未开始之前就结束了。
My mother picked me up at school and we went to the hospital.
我的母亲在学校接我去医院。
The doctor told the news with all the sensitivity that doctors lose over the years.
医生带着愧疚的情绪告诉了这个消息我们已经尽力了。
My mother cried. She did have a tiny bit of hope.
我的母亲哭了，她仅存的一点点希望也破灭了。
As I said before, everyone does.
在我说之前，所有人都这样说了。
I felt the blow.
我受到了打击。
What does it mean?
它意味着什么呢？
Wasn't it just a regular disease, the kind of disease doctors heal with a shot?
它不仅仅是一个寻常的疾病，这种疾病医生能够通过治疗使他恢复健康吗？
I hated you, dad.
我恨你，爸爸。
I felt betrayed.
我觉得自己被骗了。
I screamed with anger in the hospital, until I realized my father was not around to ground me. I cried.
我愤怒的大喊着，直到我意识到我的父亲已经不再我身边了，我哭了。
Then, my father was once again a father to me.
然后，我的父亲再次对我来说是一个遥不可及的父亲。
With a shoebox under her arm, a nurse came by to comfort me.
一个护士走过来安慰我，她的胳膊夹着一个鞋盒。
The box was full of sealed envelopes, with sentences where the address should be.
这个盒子里装满了密封的信件，这些信件上写着地址。
I couldn't understand exactly what was going on.
我不知道那上面究竟写着什么。
The nurse then handed me a letter.
然后，这个护士交给我一封信。
The only letter that was out of the box.
这是唯一一封没有放在盒子里的信。
"Your dad asked me to give you this letter. He spent the whole week writing these, and he wants you read it. Be strong." the nurse said, holding me.
护士握着我的手说；“你父亲让我把这个交给你，他用了整整一周时间写的，他要你看完它后，变得坚强。”
The envelope read WHEN I'M GONE. I opened it.
这个信封上面写着当我离去，我拆开了它。
Son,
儿子，
If you're reading this, I'm dead.
当你看到这封信时，我已经去世了。
I'm sorry. I knew I was going to die.
很抱歉，我知道我将要死去。
I didn't want to tell you what was going to happen, I didn't want to see you crying.
我不想要告诉你将发生的事，是因为我不想看到你哭。
Well, it looks like I've made it.
是的，这看起来像我故意隐瞒你。
I think that a man who's about to die has the right to act a little bit selfish.
我想一个人面对死亡时，应该有权利去做一点点自私的事。
Well, as you can see, I still have a lot to teach you.
是的，正如你所想的那样，我还有好多东西要交给你。
After all, you don't know crap about anything.
别忘了，你不要抱怨事情。
So I wrote these letters for you.
因此我写下这些信给你。
You must not open them before the right moment, OK?
你要在正确的时候拆开它们。好吗？
This is our deal.
这是我们的约定。
I love you. Take care of your mom.
我爱你，照顾好你的妈妈。
You're the man of the house now.
你现在是一家之主。
Love, dad.
爱你的父亲
PS: I didn't write letters to your mom.
P.S ：我没有给你母亲写信。
She's got my car.
她得到了我的车。
He made me stop crying with his bad handwriting.
他用他潦草的字迹使我哭个不停。
Printing was not easy back then.
用印刷体写在当时是困难的。
His ugly writing, which I barely understood, made me feel calm. It made me smile.
他潦草的字迹令我勉强才能看懂，让我保持镇定，让我微笑。
That's how my father did things.
这就是我父亲做的事情。
Like the joke before the grounding.
就像还未落地的笑话。
That box became the most important thing in the world for me.
那个盒子成为这个世界上对我来说最重要的东西。
I told my mother not to open it. Those letters were mine and no one else could read them.
我让我母亲不要拆它，那些信是我的，我不允许任何人看它。
I knew all the life moments written on the envelopes by heart.
我知道他写在信上的一生都是用心写的。
But it took a while for these moments to happen. And I forgot about it.
但是他花费了很长时间写的信，不久我就会忘记。
Seven years later, after we moved to a new place, I had no idea where I put the box. I couldn't remember it.
七年后，我们搬到一个新的地方，我不知道我把盒子放到了什么地方，我忘记了。
And when we don't remember something, we usually don't care about it.
我们不记得某事，通常是不在乎它。
If something goes lost in your memory, it doesn't mean you lost it.
如果某事在你的记忆里找不到了，那并不意味着你丢了它。
It simply doesn't exist anymore. It's like change in the pockets of your trousers.
它不过不存在了，就像是改变了你裤子上的口袋。
And so it happened.
因此它发生了。
My teenage years and my mother's new boyfriend triggered what my father had anticipated a long time before.
我的青少年时期，我母亲的新男朋友引发了我爸爸很长一段时间的观察。
My mother had several boyfriends, and I always understood it.
我的母亲有很多男朋友，我能理解。
She never married again. I don't know why, but I like to believe that my father had been the love of her life.
她从未再此结婚，我不知道原因。但是我相信我的父亲一直爱着她。
This boyfriend, however, was worthless.
然而这个男朋友，是卑微的。
I thought she was humiliating herself by dating him.
我想和他约会，我的母亲感到丢脸。
He had no respect for her. She deserved something a lot better than a guy she met at a bar.
他不尊重我的母亲，她应该做的事都比她在酒吧里遇见那个男的要好的多。
I still remember the slap she gave me after I pronounced the word "bar".
仍然记得刚我说出酒吧那个字后，她打了我一巴掌。
I'll admit that I deserved it. I learned that over the years.
我承认这是我应得的惩罚，过了很长时间，我明白了。
At the time, when my skin was still burning from the slap, I remembered the box and the letters. I remembered a specific letter, which read "WHEN YOU HAVE THE WORST FIGHT EVER WITH YOUR MOM".
在那时，当那一巴掌打的我的皮肤很滚烫时，我想起了盒子和信，想起了那个特别的信，上面写着“这可能使你和你的母亲有最坏的斗争。”
I ransacked my bedroom looking for it, which earned me another slap in the face. I found the box inside a suitcase lying on top of the wardrobe.
我彻底搜查我的床找那使我的脸挨了一巴掌的盒子，我发现这个盒子放在衣柜的最顶层的衣箱。
I looked through the letters, and realized that I had forgotten to open WHEN YOU HAVE YOUR FIRST KISS.
带着不安的状态，我浏览了信件，意识到我忘记了在我获得我的第一个吻时打开它。

I hated myself for doing that, and I decided that would be the next letter I'd open. WHEN YOU LOSE YOUR VIRGINITY came right next in the pack, a letter I was hoping to open really soon. Eventually I found what I was looking for.
我恨我自己忘记了。我决定打开接下来的那封信，接下来盒子里的是“当你失去你的贞洁时"这封信。这封我一直都希望很快打开的信，最终我发现我想要寻找的。
Now apologize to her.
现在向她道歉。
I don't know why you're fighting and I don't know who's right.
我不知道你为何吵架，我也不知道谁对。
But I know your mother.
但是我了解你的母亲。
So a humble apology is the best way to get over this.
所以一个谦逊的道歉是解决这件事最好的方式。
I'm talking about a down-on-your-knees apology.
我所说的就是一个谦逊的道歉。
She's your mother, kid.
她是你的母亲，孩子。
She loves you more than anything in this world.
她爱你胜过这个世界上的一切事物。
Do you know that she went through natural birth because someone told her that it would be the best for you?
你知道她为什么要经受顺产的痛苦生你吗、那是因为有人告诉她，那是对你最好的方法。
Have you ever seen a woman giving birth?
你有见过一个女人分娩吗？
Do you need a bigger proof of love than that?
你需要一个很大的证据来证明吗？
Apologize. She'll forgive you.
原谅她，她也会原谅你。
Love, dad.
爱你的，父亲
My father was not a great writer, he was just a bank clerk.
我的父亲并不是一个很伟大的作家，他仅是一个银行工作人员。
But his words had a great impact on me.
但是他的字对我有很大的影响力。
They were words that carried more wisdom than all of my 15 years of age at the time.
那些字上面承载着比我十五岁年龄所收获的更多的智慧。
(That wasn't very hard to achieve, though).
（尽管它很难实现。）
I rushed to my mother's room and opened the door.
我奔向我母亲的房子，打开门。
I was crying when she turned her head to look me in the eyes.
当她转过她的头用眼睛看我时，我泣不成声。
She was also crying.
她也哭了。
I don't remember what she yelled at me. Probably something like "What do you want?"
我不记得她对我喊叫，也许一些像“你想要什么？”的事情。
What I do remember is that I walked towards her holding the letter my father wrote.
我所记得是我拿着我父亲写的信走向她。
I held her in my arms, while my hands crumpled the old paper.
我用胳膊拉着她，我手心里的旧信都变皱了。
She hugged me, and we both stood in silence.
她抱住我，我们都安静的站在那里。
My father's letter made her laugh a few minutes later.
我父亲的信使我母亲笑了几分钟后。
We made peace and talked a little about him.
我们友好的聊了一会我的父亲。
She told me about some of his most eccentric habits, such as eating salami with strawberries.
她告诉我一些我父亲的古怪的习惯，例如用草莓吃萨拉米。
Somehow, I felt he was sitting right next to us.
不知怎么地，我感到父亲正坐在我们的右边。
Me, my mother and a piece of my father, a piece he left for us, on a piece of paper.
我，母亲，和我父亲的几封信，那些他留给我们的，只是一张纸。
It felt good.
它让我们觉得他一直陪伴在我们身边。
It didn't take long before I read WHEN YOU LOSE YOUR VIRGINITY
当我开始读当你失去你的贞洁这封信时并没有用很长时间。
Congratulations, son.
恭喜你，儿子：
Don't worry, it gets better with time.
不要担心，贞洁随着时间变珍贵了。
Mine happened with an ugly woman ­who was also a prostitute.
我的给了一个丑陋的妓女。
My biggest fear is that you'd ask your mother what virginity is after reading what's on the letter.
我最大的恐慌是你读完这封信后不要去问你母亲什么是贞洁。
Or even worse, reading what I just wrote without knowing what jerking off is (you know what it is, right?).
更糟糕的是，读我刚写的这个竟不知道什么是手淫。（你知道它，对吗？）
But that's none of my business.
但这与我无关。
Love, dad.
爱你的，父亲
My father followed me through my entire life. He was with me, even though he was not near me.
我的父亲一直存在于我整个人生中，尽管离我很远，他和我在一起。
His words did what no one else could: they gave me strength to overcome countless challenging moments in my life.
他所说的话是无人可比的。那些话给了我力量来克服生命中出现的无数的挑战。
He would always find a way to put a smile on my face when things looked grim, or clear my mind during those angry moments.
他总是在事情变得糟糕的时候，找一种方法让我脸上充满微笑。或者在我生气的时刻 让我脑子清晰。
WHEN YOU GET MARRIED made me feel very emotional.
‘ 当你结婚时’这封信使我很感动。
But not so much as WHEN YOU BECOME A FATHER.
但没有像”当你成为一个父亲“这封信使我感动。
Now you'll understand what real love is, son. You'll realize how much you love her, but real love is something you'll feel for this little thing over there.
现在你将明白什么是真正的爱，你能够意识到你有多么的爱她。但是真爱是你所感受到的小事。
I don't know if it's a boy or a girl.
我不知道是否是一个男孩或者一个女孩。
I'm just a corpse, I'm not a fortune teller.
我只是一具死尸，我不是一个算命者。
Have fun. It's a great thing.
过得开心，它是最棒的事情。
Time is gonna fly now, so make sure you'll be around.
光阴如梭，所以要确保你跟着它走。
Never miss a moment, they never come back.
不要错过任何一刻，它们永远不再回来。
Change diapers, bathe the baby, be a role model to this child.
换尿布，给小孩洗澡，成为孩子的榜样。
I think you have what it takes to be an amazing father, just like me.
我想你能够做到这些，你就能成为一个成功的父亲，就像我一样。
The most painful letter I read in my entire life was also the shortest letter my father wrote.
在我的一生中我所读过最痛苦的一封信也是我父亲写的最短的一封信。
While he wrote those four words, I believe he suffered just as much as I did living through that moment.
当他写下这四个字的时候，我相信，他刚所承受的比我那时候经历的痛苦还要多。
It took a while, but eventually I had to open WHEN YOUR MOTHER IS GONE.
过了一会儿，但最终，我还是拆开了那封名叫当你妈妈离去的信。
She is mine now.
她现在就是我
A joke.
一个玩笑。
A sad clown hiding his sadness with a smile on his makeup.
一个悲伤的小丑把他的痛苦隐藏在妆容后面的微笑中。
It was the only letter that didn't make me smile, but I could see the reason.
那是唯一一封没有使我笑的信，但是我可以明白原因。
I always kept the deal I had made with my father.
我一直在遵从我对父亲的承诺。
I never read letters before their time.
我从来没有在那时读过那封信。
With the exception of WHEN YOU REALIZE YOU'RE GAY.
除了那封当你认为你是同性恋者的时候。
Since I never thought I'd have to open this one, I decided to read it. It was one of the funniest letters, by the way.
尽管我从来没有想过我会拆开这一封，我决定赌他，顺便说一下那是最有趣的一封信。
What can I say?
我还能再说些什么？
I'm glad I'm dead.
我都已经死了。
Now, all joking aside, being half-dead made me realize that we care too much about things that don't matter much. Do you think that changes anything, son?
现在，让我们把所有的玩笑放在一边，作为一个将死的人，我意识到，我们不要太在意一些重要的事情，你认为这能改变一切吗？亲爱的儿子？
Don't be silly.
不能犯傻。
Be happy.
要快乐。
I would always wait for the next moment, the next letter. The next lesson my father would teach me.
我总是在等待下一个时刻，下一封信，我父亲所教我的下一节课。
Now that I am lying on a hospital bed, with tubes in my nose and my throat thanks to this damn cancer, I run my fingers on the faded paper of the only letter I didn't open.
当我的鼻子和喉咙由于这该死的癌症插满管子的时候，我把我的手指放在那封我唯一没有打开的泛黄的信上。
